title: Why is Pinyin often written without diacritical marks? - Quora

response.answer_text: Why are tone marks omitted? At least two reasons: (1) Inputting tones is a hassle. Besides, anybody who is fluent in Mandarin and proficient in Pinyin can easily read running text written without tone marks. Why bother? (2) Most foreigners can't pronounce tones, so why go to all the trouble of adding them? That being said, omitting tone marks on maps, street signs and documents intended for foreign audiences (passports, diplomas, leases, books, magazines, newspapers etc.) does cause confusion. Totally unrelated names that differ by tone are mixed together, thus helping to reinforce unfortunate foreign stereotypes of Chinese: “They all look alike and even their names are almost the same”. Street addresses can also cause confusion. In Taipei, for example, there are two roads called “Wuchang Street”: 武昌街 and 五常街 (completely different characters and different tones). I’m sure there are similar examples in other Chinese cities, something that Chinese rarely notice because they only read the Chinese characters.  *Solutions* Adding numbers to represent tones looks “weird”, unsightly and is apt to be ignored (no other language uses numbers to spell people’s names). Besides, many people are bothered by looking at what appear to be formulas in a math textbook. Augmented Pinyin, which marks tones by adding 4 letters at the end of each syllable, is an ideal solution to the problem of marking tones without diacritics (of course, teaching materials and dictionaries wouldn’t need to be changed).  Mnemonic Basis for HJMN: H, M and N are composed of two vertical lines. The middle portion looks exactly like Hanyu Pinyin’s tone marks, and the letter J looks like the top half of “2”. What’s more, the syllables can be arranged in alphabetical order. 除此之外 can be romanized thus   Here are four real people whose names sound quite different, but whose passport spellings would be the same. HJMN Augmented Pinyin restores their dignity while maintaining Hanyu Pinyin spellings, thus maintaining continuity: 徐建良 Xu Jianliang - - > Xuj Jiannliangj 許建良 Xu Jianliang - - > Xum Jiannliangj 徐兼良 Xu Jianliang - - > Xuj Jianhliangj 許兼良Xu Jianliang - - > Xum Jianhliangj  PRC National Standard GB / T16159-1996 specifies that alternative methods can also be used to mark tones. Here is the relevant section: 《漢語拼音正詞法基本規則》 Hànyǔ Pīnyīn Zhèngcífǎ Jīběn Guīzé/Hannyeu Pinin Jenqtsyrfaa Jibeen Gueitzer “Basic Rules of Hanyu Pinyin Orthography”: 中華人民共和國國家標准Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó Guójiā Biāozhǔn “People's Republic of China National Standard” GB / T16159-1996 標調 4.11.1 … 注：除了《漢語拼音方案》規定的符號法以外，在技術處理上，也可根據需要采用數字或字母作爲臨時變通標調法。 Tone Marking 4.11.1 … NOTE: In addition to the symbols prescribed in the "the Pinyin Scheme for the Chinese Language", when technical reasons make it necessary, numbers or letters may also be used on occasion as alternative methods of marking tones. HJMN is a perfect “alternative method of marking tones”

Probably because these marks are hard to be typed on keyboard. The keyboard map widely used by Pinyin users is similar to US keyboard, which doesn't include alternative keys or AltGr kry to add marks on letters. The only way is to call an alternative keyboard map which only contains vowel letters with marks. In fact, when written on paper (especially on books targeting on children in China or on dictionaries), diacritical marks are probably always written. The diacritical marks are forced to be used everywhere proper. After all, it could be confusing when without them. Maybe you've seen that the names for regions and names are often written without marks. I noticed that it was pushed in a document: 国发［1978］192号1978年9月26日《国务院批转关于改用汉语拼音方案作为我国人名地名罗马字母拼写法的统一规范的报告》(State Council [1978]#192 1978-09-26 "State Council's Approval of the report to use Hanyu Pinyin as the united standard to spell Chinese names and region namrs") . In Article 13 of the last annex, “在电信中，对不便于传递和不符合电信特点的拼写形式可以作技术性的处理，如用yu代ü等。” (In electronic communications, technical deal can be pressed on the spelling form that are not easy to transport or not appreciate to electronic communications, like use " yu" to represent "ü") So, when we have trouble using the correct form, we can hide those diacritical marks.
